Abstract: Active vision is a focus topic in the field of computer vision. Designing and constructing active vision systems which perform different visual functions analogous to those of human vision system is considered as the core of the subject. In this paper, we describe our work on the design and construction of NJU head-eye platform which is similar to but different in many aspects from the KTH head developed in CVAP, Royal Institute of Technology of Sweden. The NJU head consists of two eye modules, each of which can perform its own independent pan and tilt motions. A neck module drives the head to perform pan and tilt motions which are independent of those of the eye modules. In addition, the two cameras of the head-eye platform can focus and zoom according to the changing environments. The length of the baseline of the binocular system is adjustable.

Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering
Abstract: Knowing the effectiveness of a test suite is essential for many activities such as guiding the generation of new test cases and assessing the test adequacy of code. Mutation testing is a commonly used defect injection technique for evaluating the effectiveness of a test suite. However, it is usually computationally expensive, as a large number of mutants (buggy versions) are needed to be generated from a production code under test and executed against the test suite. In order to reduce the expensive testing cost, recent studies proposed to use supervised models to predict the effectiveness of a test suite without executing the test suite against the mutants. Nonetheless, the training of such a supervised model requires labeled data, which still depends on the costly mutant execution. Furthermore, existing models are based on traditional supervised learning techniques, which assumes that the training and testing data come from the same distribution. But, in practice, software systems are subject to considerable concept drifts, i.e. the same distribution assumption usually does not hold. This can lead to inaccurate predictions of a learned supervised model on the target code as time progresses. To tackle these problems, in this paper, we propose a Coverage-Based Unsupervised Approach (CBUA) for evaluating the effectiveness of a test suite. The whole process only requires a one-time execution of the test suite against the target production code, without involving any mutant execution and any training data. CBUA can ensure the score monotonicity property (i.e. adding test cases to a test suite does not decrease its mutation score), which may be violated by a supervised approach. The experimental results show that CBUA is very competitive to the state-of-the-art supervised approaches in terms of the prediction accuracy. Since CBUA is an easy-to-implement model with a low cost, we suggest that it should be used as a baseline approach for comparison when any novel prediction approach is proposed in future studies.
